title: DPIA Requirement Check
description: Helps decide whether a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is required based on the nature of processing. This is a generic, jurisdiction-neutral guide.

personal_data.text: Does this activity involve processing personal data?

No.explanation: If no personal data is processed, a DPIA is not required. You may still document a basic risk assessment for governance purposes.

high_risk_characteristics.text:
Does the processing involve any of the following high-risk characteristics?

- Systematic monitoring (e.g. CCTV, tracking, monitoring behaviour)
- Large-scale processing of personal data
- Special category / highly sensitive data (health, biometrics, children, financial, criminal)
- Vulnerable individuals or power imbalance (patients, employees, students, beneficiaries)
- Use of new or intrusive technology (AI profiling, behavioural scoring, monitoring tools)

Yes, one or more apply.explanation: Your processing has one or more high-risk characteristics. A DPIA is strongly recommended and may be mandatory under many data protection regimes.

borderline_context.text: Even if none of the high-risk characteristics clearly apply, is there any context that still makes this activity feel risky (e.g. reputational risk, complex data sharing, cross-border transfers)?

Yes, it still feels risky.explanation: A formal DPIA may not be strictly mandatory, but documenting a DPIA-style assessment will help you evidence that you considered risks and mitigations.

No, it is clearly low risk.explanation: Based on your answers, a formal DPIA is unlikely to be required. Still keep a simple record of your reasoning and basic controls.
